The question of how likely or unlikely we are to encounter (or have encountered) aliens rests largely upon the laws of physics.

If there are ways to overcome the speed of light as a limiting factor (via wormholes, some manipulation of gravity or some quantum weirdness), and if intelligent, curious life is common enough, then the probability of alien interaction starts to rise significantly.

Conversely, if we truly are approaching a “theory of everything”, and as a species we are truly as special as we’re again starting to think, then the probability is extremely low.

I see no good evidence for or against either of these possibilities.

What we know: space and time are truly infinite. Energy and matter keep converting into one another.

How much universe is visible to us? If we think our universe is X years old, we couldn't have seen anything beyond X light years in radius (assuming earth is stationary). So let's say till now we have seen our universe that's Y light years in radius (given that we are actually in motion). Now imagine a space on a scale where Y light years is equal to radius of an atom. At this scale our entire 'visible' universe is merely an atom.

So is it possible that aliens exist? I think it's possible that not only aliens exists, but every permutation and combination that people talk about when they talk about butterfly effect very well can exist because space is that infinite. But do they exist at the same time? It's equally less likely :)

Also my answer to the first question is yes, but also what if....
Imagine, if we search for life in all of our observable universe (every single planet is even explored/looked at) and we still find nothing. Does that mean there is no life out there? No. It could just mean that life is so uncommon that it's sprinkled across the infinite universe, so far away in design, that life cannot tell if they are alone or not because they are too far apart. If this were true, the only life we could end up seeing would either be life that is unlikely to be close to us, or, life that has somehow figured out how to travel outside of the horizon of their observable universe (faster than the speed of light? or some other means?) and somehow knew exactly where we are at. Both seem impossible but one has to be true, I think.

This is why I can confidently say that yes 100% life is out there, but the probability of us meeting there (or even being in the same observable universe) is less than 1%.

My answer:
Almost certainly. We exist, and there's billions of other stars and planets out there. And there's even life on Earth that could potentially survive on other moons and maybe a planet or two in our own solar system.

Whether or not they've visited Earth is a different story. I am very open to say both they have or they haven't. Just show me the definitive evidence. The scale of the universe and the distances to travel are indeed extremely vast. But Earth formed 4.5 billion years ago, which is much later than the first planets which got started about 11 billion years ago. Life appeared on Earth 3.5 billion years ago and land life appeared ~500 million years ago. It took less than a million years for complex animals much like the ones we see today to begin roaming the Earth, and the dinosaurs first roamed the Earth less than 250 million years ago.

This means that it's not unlikely that somewhere is a species that lives on an 8 billion year old rock where life appeared in the same stages and took the same amount of time. And a sentient species on that planet may have avoided any dark ages or technological stints and gained literally billions of years of technological advancement before humans even existed. And those same beings may have very well figured out how to build a warp drive to travel around the cosmos potentially infinitely fast. And for all we know we may crack this technology tomorrow.

With this reasoning and understanding, the biggest reason aliens would not have visited us on Earth is simply that the universe is so freaking big that we may just get missed, stepped over, or just not be anywhere near any of these kinds of civilizations. Finding our particular world may be like trying to find an individual blade of grass on Earth. We've mapped all of Earth, but individual blades of grass are so common we just can't even care about where they are or whether or not we've found any fraction of them all.

I think if there were a hyper advanced civilization billions of years ahead of us, we would be like a blade of grass under them, super easy to step over and miss. Impossible to care about individually.

Actually, it's a Paradox. There is just as much possibility them not existing as existing.. the size of the universe doesn't add probability, nor does it deflate probability..so there is a strong possibility they don't exist hence given the size. Just a thought but if the universe really is infinite in its size because of expansion, then couldn't be possibly something that has quickly replicated itself like a Hologram or you sitting doing the Copy and Paste X amount of times. Excuse my semantics but you don't need to buy into the holographic principle. Some people might argue given its infinity, it hints more of a wasteland with nothing in than something ordered and compact. (Not entropy) while I wouldn't go as far as to agree with them, it's worth noting that we have whole solar systems, millions of them detected with no life on, which is so hard to contemplate the size.. 100 earth's can fit inside Jupiter. Jupiter can't even be landed on. So the odds are slim.. despite given the infinite chances. Paradoxically, if the universe is infinite, we might just have to wait for a loonggg time for conditions to be right, maybe even we don't need to count expansion, we just need conditions to be right in our own sol system. Unfortunately, we probably won't exist then. The size of the universe doesn't imply E.T size doesn't matter. I laugh when people even go as far as to go Aliens have visited the earth in Ships. I don't mind the lack of scientific culture of the interviewees but the argumentation backing that "We're not about to have any proof of extraterrestrial life soon." idea surprised me a lot more : Veritasium is used to being more subtle, I think.

I like him to be serious and not opened to any conspiracy theory but maybe he could have given a little more time to examine the elements that make some people believe that life is not a rare thing in this Universe, and that contact may have already happened.

I know it's nearly an heresy for contemporary scientists but, even to disprove it, the tact and kindness of Derek could be suited, had he only exposed and commented some of the ordinary facts that "believers" argue.

I mean, the Billy Meier case for example, puts a ton of photos and videos of flying saucers on the table, as well as testimonies of encounters and discussions with other beings. It has been examined quite seriously (photo analysis, lie detector ...).

If those informers are not considered trust worthy, one could comment and criticize the testimonies of astronauts, or even ex-military personnel involved in the "Disclosure" initiative. That thing is becoming quite big. You can hear hundreds of hours of insiders talking about revolutionary propulsion technologies being developed since the fifties, and even crazier stories mentioning the cooperation of humans and ETs.

Again, I know Veritasium is not about conspiracies and fake news, so I'm not asking him to confirm any of that, but I just think it is strange to do a "Do aliens exist ?" video and not even acknowledge all that material. He could be very helpful to help putting some light on this obscure topic.

With respect your naivety is astounding! Why would any member of an advanced intraterrestrial or extraterrestrial civilization want to communicate with someone of your limited intellectual capabilities? I am not trying to insult you. I'm just stating a fact. You don't even know the true history of your planet, let alone how it is managed. Furthermore, your knowledge of astronomy is based on primitive concepts which, in a few centuries, will be regarded with the same disdain as that of modern physicists who laugh at the notion that the Earth was once believed to be the centre of the universe by medieval astronomers.

THE EMERGENCE OF EXTRATERRESTRIAL LIFE WAS INEVITABLE

If a universal God exists and it created ideal conditions for life to evolve only on Earth then this God would not be very intelligent. What intelligent God would create a fertile planet surrounded by a vast and sterile universe? The reality of the situation is that the four known forces which govern the behaviour of matter and energy are calibrated to such a degree of perfection that it is inconceivable that they were not predetermined to create the conditions for life to appear in all its various forms throughout the universe. Intellectually and mathematically, the postulate that life exists only on Earth is both naive and absurd. But if intelligent extraterrestrial life exists in the Galaxy, why have they not contacted us? Where are they located and what would they look like? These are the questions that have always been asked by an uninformed public. Unfortunately the people most qualified to answer these questions such as biologists, physicists, philosophers, chemists, astronomers and religious intellectuals have, for the most part, always claimed that we are alone in the Universe. Historically they have always been wrong because they have not had access to all the information that exists on the subject which is reserved only for a minority of privileged and very powerful people in the world and unfortunately that does not include you.

I find it amusing that people like you don't even realize that Earth was conquered long ago and is in a region of the galaxy dominated by a species called the Alpha Draconians. Impossible you say? Not necessarily! So how would a hostile species tackle the problem of dominating another species? It is probable that the preferred method of controlling a planet for a highly intelligent and technologically advanced malevolent race of extraterrestrials would be covert infiltration rather than by obvious and violent force. Moreover, as a general rule, one does not destroy what one can control so the most logical strategy would be to control the leadership of the planet, its political, military and economic establishments but more importantly, the secret societies, affiliations and clubs which control these establishments. Conquering a species that doesn't know it has been conquered is the mark of superior intelligence. Obviously some people may doubt the existence of malevolent extraterrestrials in the first place. Why would they exist at all? The answer is that the universe would be a much less interesting and dynamic place if various species were not pushed to their limits in order to survive and evolve. Without conflict and struggle to survive in highly competitive environments, there would be no incentive to adapt and change. As a consequence, the process of evolution would slow down dramatically and the plethora of unique species that exist today would also decrease significantly. For intelligent and technological species, this eternal struggle is a philosophical one between the precepts of malevolence and benevolence. In other words between the desire to dominate other species or being subjugated oneself. It would also be the contrast between autocratic self-serving behaviour or believing in freedom, equality and democracy. Ironically without the existence of emotions in many extraterrestrial species in the universe, it is doubtful that benevolent species would exist at all because if all actions and behaviour are deemed to be acceptable without limits, then the emergence of a code of ethics cannot occur. In a certain sense, this philosophical struggle corresponds to the yin and yang in Chinese philosophy which describes how apparently opposite and contrary forces are actually complementary. More precisely, each serves as a reference point for the other. Fortunately the capacity for emotions such as pleasure and pain serve as a strong foundation for the emergence of a code of ethics among most intelligent species in the universe.

Hopefully you will now understand that the universe is teeming with life. It has always been this way and will always be this way. I cannot expect you to understand why these cycles are eternal because your brain is psychologically programmed to understand absolutes and quantifiable events in finite terms. In this context the belief that the universe is approximately 13 billion years old and has boundaries is as quaint as it is inaccurate.

Ok. Guys. Even before scrolling down to the comments I knew the most prevalent ones would be "Wow, look at all these stupid people". What, personally, gives me far less hope for humanity is not the people depicted in the video, not knowing what a light year or a galaxy is, but these comments and people who make them.

When you belittle people for not knowing certain things you are not encouraging them to pursue that knowledge you are actively embarrassing them and putting them below the average person; and you are making society worse. I am more than certain that all of you out there are been discouraged, by another person, from doing something because you "sucked at it". It's not a nice feeling, and you've missed out on doing some incredible things because of it.

If a child says something like "A light year is probably 150 human years" not many people would bat an eye, they would just think it's cute and tussle the child's hair. ^God forbid^ an adult not know something that has nothing to do with their work or lifestyle. ^Because as we all know^, when we age all facets of our knowledge increase at the same rate. So, at the age of 21, ^we all know^ galaxies contain billions of stars and how to properly change a tyre and on what day of the week D-day happened on. If you don't know just one of those things then "you're stupid" and are essentially being an oxygen thief to the rest of us ^highly intelligent beings^.

Understand that all knowledge and all skill has to be accumulated at some point, some people start later than others. A massive outlet for human misery at the moment is someone starts something and because of their age or background they are expected to know better. People do not start amazing at anything. If they do there is probably something similar they've done in the past to help them, and even then they could still be bad at it. Be nice to those at the bottom of the ladder, it'll be a huge drive to climb it.

I'm sure a fair few of you would argue "this is common knowledge" or "this was taught in school, there's no excuse to not know this". Who gets to define "common knowledge"? I'm sure something as mundane as changing a tyre is common knowledge but a fair majority of people reading this don't know how to do it. Also, plenty of things are taught in school that people forget because they don't *use it*. I remember there being wood work classes but I have completely forgotten all facets of it because I have not wood-worked since. Do I not like wood-work? No, I like it but my home didn't have the facilities for me to pursue that hobby.

The distances are huge but the times are huge too. We have a huge bias toward human life spans, and toward modern approximately 10,000 years of record keeping human history. This bias ignores the fact that a billion years from now we'll have a billion years of recorded history of progress with our biology and our space faring ability. To assume we'll still be limited to things that take less than a hundred years to accomplish is very very provincial in both time and space. There's no reason that someone hasn't started not 100 years before now, but more like a billion or even 5 billion years before now, plenty of time to span not just the milky way, but all of the 1,000 or so galaxies in the nearby virgo super-cluster. It's an ignorance of time that makes it seem unlikely we'd be visited. Once you take time into account the Fermi paradox is really a paradox. Where is everybody?

I like to answer Veritasiums questions at the start of the video

Do I think there is life beyond the earth? Yes, not very confidently but the sheer volume of "beyond the earth" as well as the strong nature of replication to propagate makes me think it's well within the realm of possibility.

Do I think that aliens have ever come to earth? If we're talking sentient beings then no. The odds of them finding us would be tiny and whatever tech they had to cross the interstellar or intergalactic distance would almost certainly leave a detectable energy signal that no conspiracy could really cover up.

What is a galaxy? A galaxy is an independent cluster of stars and other material gravitationaly collected together. The milky wa is our galaxy. Galaxies tend to contain stars in the order of hundreds of billions although some exist with only hundreds of millions.

What is a light year? A light year is the unit of distance that light in a vacuum can travel in a year. From memory it's 2.9 x 10^15m [Looked this up after it's about 9.5 x 10^15m]

Have I heard the term exoplanet? Yes. It's a planet outside of our...I'm not sure if it's outside our solar system or outside our galaxy, although I can't think of a term for a planet in the milky way but not in our solar system so I'd guess outside our solar system.

I'm glad he doesn't do these "man-on-the-street"-style videos anymore. I just feel bad for the people he interviews. Sure, those people are totally ignorant when it comes to matters of science, but presumably they never claimed to be science experts in the first place.

If someone approached me with a camera and started asking me basic questions about science, well, frankly, I'd do quite well. But if they asked about, say, geography, car mechanics, classic literature, sports, or music, I'd look like an idiot.

The fact that he seems to think (or thought in 2013) that his viewership gets a condescending feeling of superiority from watching him humiliate suckers on the street is revealing -- he thinks rather poorly of his viewers' moral character.

Thankfully, he's now abandoned this mode of presentation, and his channel is one of the best on YouTube these days. He should consider deleting his old videos, out of respect for the poor suckers who agreed to reveal their ignorance on camera.

I loved the video @veritasium but like most other videos which focus on the question - 'are there aliens out there?', even this misses out on an important aspect.

I agree that there is no definite evidence suggesting that there is alien life out there, but considering the sheer size of the universe, one cannot rule out the probability.

The missing aspect is motivation. Let me explain.

We earthlings lack the motivation to answer the question definitively. Is that wrong? No. Why? Because we have more pressing matters to solve on this planet itself. Finding another planet with life is not a unified cause for all the people on earth (governments, when I mean people). We do have some organizations who keep researching on it, but it's just not enough. At the current rate of R&D into the field, the possibility of finding a planet with life doesn't exist. Unless all of the governments (most powerful ones at least) in our world take this question as a priority, pool their resources and talent, and really focus on it for a substantial time, we won't have an answer for sure.

Having said that, there is another issue. Lets consider that there is actually a planet outside our solar system which very much resembles earth and can sustain life. If we manage to locate that planet, the first course of action will be to try and send communication signals. By doing so, we're assuming (or hoping) that there is an intelligent life on the planet which can receive our radio signals and possibly reply.

The motivation will take a beating if we do not receive a reply. Even if there is an intelligent life form on the planet, we'd be assuming that they use radio or even understand the concept of it.

My question lies here.. Will there be enough motivation left for us to globally fund and organize a space programme to send an orbiter or satellite close enough to the planet to try and get answers.

Even if we decide on doing that, we currently do not have the technology to reach there fast enough. These planets are light years away from us, mind you. Nobody living on earth today is going to live long enough to receive answers. We'll be hoping that tens of forthcoming generations will continue the programme. That's a big assumption. Also, we're ruling out the fact that the equipment that we send out today, will become technologically obsolete before it even reaches half way to the planet.

So unless we invent warp drive, the feasibility of the whole 'search for definitive answers' is negligible.

Knowing all these aspects, it's highly unlikely that we would have enough motivation to carry out such a massive mission, investing a hell lot of money, talent and resources, where the same can be used here, on earth, to solve more important issues we're dealing with everyday.

So we just sit back on earth, shooting radio signals at planets we think might have intelligent life, in a hope that somebody might listen, decode and reply back.

There is a very high probability of existence of aliens, but there also a high probability of not finding it anytime soon.

So only 3 possibilities really exist, we're rare, we're first, or we're fucked.(Fermi Paradox)

We're rare: The filter that prevents life really DOES exist (finding any signs of life at all on titan/mars/ect. would disprove this), and we've somehow made it through and it actually is so rare to make it through that we may be largely alone (still a low chance of completely alone).

We're first: We were the first life forms to evolve to the point of our current intelligence, personally this isn't that bad of an idea when you think of how young the universe still is to be honest. But still 13 billion years to create life as simple as us? Seems unlikely too.

We're fucked: We haven't hit the filter yet, life itself may be very common, but the true test as a species may still be coming and it could be very unlikely we survive it. (I believe the super predator theory fits here as well).

But even with all of this Boltzmann Brain still guarantees we won't always be alone.

There's more then likely life out there, but...

By the sheer distance between us and them, we'll probably never meet any aliens unless moving faster then light is possible, or distorting space to go beyond normal speeds.

For example, the nearest solar system to us is about 4.3 light years away.

I know of only one feasible argument for why we might be the only life, but it's a little long to write out here. Just look up biocentrism. Since a conscious observer collapses probability waves of particles merely by observing them (look up double-slit experiment and delayed quantum choice eraser), it stands to reason that the entire universe, being made of particles, is evolving as we observe it and collapse it down to its most likely state. In this view, the universe does not create life, but life creates the universe in which it lives. IT may seem a little out there, but the argument has some scientific merit.

The sad part is, likelihood of life existing somewhere seems very high, but what kind of life and in what state of development, that's more problematic. If one were to look at earth at any point of its existence, chances are there wont be any humans around, much less living in a technologically advanced society. So even if there's tons of planets with life on them, most will probably be micro-organisms, and most of the rest would have some variation of un-intelligent organisms. Probably. Judging by just 1 planet, our own, it's hardly easy to predict if intelligence or society-building are things that would occur on most planets with multi-cellular lifeforms... I mean, we only know of 1 occurence on earth itself, primates... many other intelligent animals exist, but the conditions for them to ever build a civilisation in the absence of humans seem to be difficult if not impossible to meet (i.e why would a dolphin evolve arm-like appendages and start building tools).
So while the huge number of planets makes it plausible for life to exist, and while I personally believe intelligent life would probably also exist there, the incredible distances that separate us from them are depressing... not only in space, but also in time. What if thousands of civilisations had existed in the past, now all extinct... what if we go extinct before meeting an "alien" society... also, what if we can never travel the millions of light years that may separate us from them.

Also... like others, I must remark on the people you chose to present in the video... I know the average knowledge of people in any particular field is usually pretty disappointing, but man, most geeks would at least know what galaxies or lightyears are...

Yes. Aliens exist. I know, because I saw a UFO once.

Actually, what I saw, were two lights hovering at the end of my street. After my attention was drawn to them, by this white spotlight, shining through my apartment kitchen window. At first, I thought the spotlight must be workmen up the pole at the end of the street. Even though that had never happened before. Walking into the kitchen as it skittered across the floor, I noticed the spotlight was asymmetrical, and more penetrating than a normal light. It had shafts within shafts in it. Just like the spotlights depicted in Close Encounters Of The Third Kind. Just.plain.weird.

Reaching the window, I peered into the darkness. What I saw, were two lights hovering, seemingly at the end of the street. One was red, the other was blue, or green. Can't remember which anymore. The white spotlight was gone. The two colored lights, were about the size of a car tire. Though I can not attest to my scaling abilities. And seemed to be attached to a craft of some kind. Because the lights remained a fixed distance apart. They did not flicker or flit about independently. And when the lights moved, they still remained fixed.

I strained and strained to see better, to see more. To see if I could make out an outline. But could not; it was just too dark. As my mind reeled at the thought, I just might be looking at an alien craft, the lights hovered down the street perpendicular to mine. With trees, and houses behind it, along with wires in front and back. A very tight spot for a flying saucer. With the lights still visible to me, it then slowly moved down a parallel street. At first, I hoped this would offer a chance to see more of whatever it was, as it would be hovering past a street light. But with the colored lights now angling away from me, and buildings now getting in the way, that did not happen.

I thought about clambering down the apartment stairs, to get a better look. But it was 2 or 3 in the morning, was winter, and I was barefoot in a robe, and nearly 300 pounds. Just was not going to happen. So I walked across my apartment, to the living room window, and waited for the lights to reappear, at the other end of the parallel street. That would put them a lot closer to me. Perfect. But they did not reappear. I never saw the two lights again. An experience never repeated.

And no, I did not have a camera ready. If I had, it would not have mattered. It all happened too fast, and would not have been discernible anyway. The conditions were impossible.

And yes, I could be lying. I could be mentally ill. I could have been drunk, or on drugs, or dreaming, or hallucinating. Maybe I'm a prankster, or a troll. Maybe I'm a narcissist after attention. Maybe I'm a straight gay bisexual tranny looking to get a TV show. All of this could be true, and more.

Or maybe, the lights were a natural phenomenon. Along with the SPOTLIGHT straight out of Close Encounters.

Or maybe, it was an experimental government project of some kind. But I doubt it. This happened about 20 years ago. How would it be possible for our dumb-ass government to keep it a secret so long? Because if it has, I am impressed. It would be a first. Our government could not even keep nuclear weaponry a secret. Or e-mails.

But that's my UFO story. It's okay if you don't believe me. It's even okay if you don't believe I'm 130 pounds lighter, thanks to my Gold's treadmill and Total Gym. Nobody in my life (sniff sniff) believes my UFO story either. Not even the sister who wants me to believe, a duplex she once lived in, is haunted.

I suspect it's not and this number has a lot to do with local mass densities and local gravitational field strengths. What we perceive as a long distance is only a reflection of our our current technologies, aliens might consider the Earth's distance from them no more than a pop to the shop for a bottle of milk. A core argument that's missing in this video is time. Over cosmical timescales of billions of years, it's extremely unlikely that life develops on Earth and somewhere else exactly simultaneously. And since "we" (life on Earth) have come relatively late, chances are that other life was sooner. This again would allow for a civilization to develop much further -- at the time that we only come into appearance, "they" might have colonized entire galaxies. Space is vast, but millions of years of development allow for a small part of it to become reachable. Yet, there has not been a single scientific evidence of extraterrestrial life, although programs like SETI have run for half a century. So, where is everybody?

Welcome to the Fermi Paradox.

It's sad when otherwise very intelligent people claim that the probability of life elsewhere is anything but unknown.

We don't know the probability for life elsewhere, at least partially because we don't know the probability for life here on Earth. We don't know how abiogenesis, life from not-life, happened, and we don't know the probability of it happening, not even with a carbon copy of Earth. We don't know how close another planet has to be to the qualities of Earth for it to be able to sustain life.
When we don't know these probabilities, it doesn't matter how many Earth-like planets there are.

The number of Earth-like planets is likely rather high, let's call that number z. And let's call the probability of life happening on an Earth-like planet for q. Then the likely number of planets with life on them are z times q. But if q is, say, one in every ten thousand z, then the probability for life elsewhere is rather low.
The point is, we don't know what the probability is, other than above zero.

To take Drak's Equation. We don't know what fl is. And any guess on what it is, is just that, a guess. It's not even an informed one, because we really don't know how life begun, nor under what parameters it can do so. It probably requires somewhat complex organic structures (and lucky they are not that rare), but other than that, we are still completely in the dark.

Irrespective of people's understanding of the shear vastness of the universe, using that as an argument to suggest extraterrestrial life either could never or would never visit this planet is a completely flawed logic.

Even using our current understanding of physics it is mathematically possible to warp space time to allow vast distances, yes even galactic in scale, to be traversed.

Now this in no way proves that ETs have, would or could travel here. However I think those who categorically dismiss the possibility are making an argument no more intelligently thought out than those who claim that it has, or is happening.

The point is, until the subject is treated in a mature fashion and the stigma removed from those who wish to investigate the question of have we or are we being visited, we will never have anything more than uniformed speculation on the subject.

There is a law out there, similar to Murphy's law, and it states that what can exist, must exist. Meaning this: If there are the necessary requirements in space for something to exist, there is no reason it shouldn't (Which is why people are so confused as to why there is as much lithium in the universe as there is, when there could, and should be much, much more). This concept is also what we thought of Black Holes at first. Before we actually discovered them, there was just a possibility they could exist. Where I'm going with this is if the necessary requirements for life can exist, therefore they must exist somewhere out there in the vastness of the universe. And what do you know, there is someplace this HAS occurred. Can you guess where? Yes, right here on Earth. So why couldn't it exist somewhere else, if we have seen these necessary requirements turn up not once, twice, or three times, but 62 times (And counting). Therefore, by this law It is not inconceivable to say life can and must exist somewhere out there, whether it be in -500 degrees or 500 degrees Fahrenheit.

Drakes Equation tries to explain the probability of detecting extra terrestrial life. Considering the amount of galaxies and planets within those galaxies, there's a high chance of life existing elsewhere. Although I think the chances of anyone visiting Earth is very improbable, even if a civilisation had the technology to travel faster than the speed of light, or warp space time. 
If you scale that idea down, and ask this question - Has anyone on Earth visited every single city, town and village, in every country and on every continent?
The answer is obvioulsy no.
The amount of planets in the whole universe exceeds the number of our towns/cities by several billion, so the chances are, that they haven't got around to planet Earth yet.
Maybe one day though, we'll be lucky - or unlucky.
Unless of course, we were seeded by aliens in the first place. If this were true, then my first question would be why? 
But I don't think I want to know the answer.

N = R* • fp • ne • fl • fi • fc • L

N = The number of civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy whose electromagnetic emissions are detectable.
R* =The rate of formation of stars suitable for the development of intelligent life.
fp = The fraction of those stars with planetary systems.
ne = The number of planets, per solar system, with an environment suitable for life.
fl = The fraction of suitable planets on which life actually appears.
fi = The fraction of life bearing planets on which intelligent life emerges.
fc = The fraction of civilizations that develop a technology that releases detectable signs of their existence into space.
L = The length of time such civilizations release detectable signals into space.

My 8th grade science teacher put this in an amazing context for me. He said if you took a million ants and spread them randomly over a desert and each ant represented one space faring civilization in our galaxy, the odds are that the vast majority of those ants would reach the limit of their lifespan before ever encountering another of the million ants. 
Such would be civilizations in our galaxy. Humanity is one ant in a desert and we have not even learned how to leave our little grain of sand yet. The odds a greatly against us surviving long enough as a species to meet another ant in our desert.

Another issue with finding out if there is life outside our solar system is the lifespan of the (theorized) life on the other planet and their technology. The chances of life being on other planets is very high, however the chance that they are able to contact us is very low due to them being long dead, or too far away for us ever to know they existed. The distance between us and other life is most likely thousands of lightyears which means if they can even relay any sort of information at the speed of light, there is a slim chance we will receive it before our species dies out, or is the other life form even capable of relaying such a message because even after several thousands of years ourselves the farthest message we have sent out is one of Hitlers speeches during WWII which has only traveled 65 light years to the star HD 217107. I thought you were going to mention Fermi's Paradox - where is everyone?  I love thinking about possible explanations.  

There are the more mundane ones, like life is exceedingly rare or possibly unique to Earth, the great filter hypothesis that states most life encounters an event that wipes it out and we got lucky enough to go beyond it, or the distances are just too vast to traverse.  

But then there are some really crazy, conspiracy-esque explanations like we are in a simulation, aliens are just watching us waiting until we become advanced enough, there are super aliens that conquer and destroy civilizations when they become advanced, sufficiently advanced civilizations stop being biological and live virtually without caring about the physical world, or when civilizations become advanced enough they create super AI's that take over and destroy the biological life.

This topic kind of straddles the science-philosophy boundary, but it's still fun and could be worth a video...

My theory on aliens:
Part A- Aliens have three options to existence relative to time. They existed in the past, the exist along side us in the present, or they are waiting to be formed in the future.
Part B- There are different kinds of aliens which may exist. Microbial, plant, small animal (unintelligent), large animal (unintelligent), and variations of the small and large animals with intelligence. This is to include all the more specific variations from one type of life to the other (in an evolutionary scale). 
Part C- The likelihood of discovering one of these aliens or the existence of it entirely depends upon the complexity of the organism. Meaning microbial organisms have the highest chances of being found and are more abundant than all the other species because they are the most simplistic lifeforms to exist. Here is an order which entails its complexity and likelihood of it's existence. Micro-organisms, plants, unintelligent small animals/large animals, intelligent animals.
Part D- Aliens (which are intelligent) have not made contact with us for these reasons:
-1. They have no benefit in doing so
-2. They do not know of our existence
-3. They have no way of doing so
-4. They are, but the transmission is taking light years to reach us
-5. They are not intelligent like mankind (meaning no existence of intelligent life)
-6. They did in the long history Homo Sapiens possess and have completed their objectives for having anything to do with us.
Part E- Extinction of some kind has wiped them out (refer to Part A where it says past) so we can only find remains of alien life

Conclusion: I believe they exist but in very small numbers and there is an even a smaller number which could pose to be intelligent if at all because they have yet to evolve or have already existed and have gone extinct (maybe they could repeat the evolutionary cycle to form again?). This means by the time mankind has a successful search (through probability). The hope is that we find microbial life before our extinction though which I believe can be done and that this form of alien life does exist. 

Part F- Bonus part!!! What did I miss in my explanation and what did not make sense? Please input your thoughts in a replied comment to my post so that I can analyze your words and improve my theory. :D

I feel the chance that life, whether intelligent or not, exists on other planets is far too great to discount. In fact, I feel that many intelligent races have existed, exist in this time frame, and will exist in the future. The universe is incomprehensibly vast and it, by our calculations, is roughly 13.8 billion years old. Our existence of less than 200,000 years makes up for only 0.0000145 of the universe's age, so there has been plenty of time for other species to form and evolve. There are over 200 billion stars and possibly even more planets in this galaxy alone, and I'm sure some of those are rocky, have an atmosphere, are within the Goldilocks zone, and possess suitable gravity and climate conditions for life to evolve. Even if those planets make up 0.000001 of them all, there would still be 200,000 habitable planets. And just because one may not be suitable for human's doesn't mean other forms of life can't thrive.

Interstellar clouds containing DNA precursors float through space, and things like meteorites can pass through these and go on to seed these planets. These DNA precursors form DNA's bases as well as amino acids which in turn leads to the creation of simple, single celled organisms which then branch off and mutate many many times over until you have increasingly more complex organisms. So that chance that other races may exist is much high than some may think.

People seem to think that they can make a judgement call as to the probability of life elsewhere by whether alien beings have visited the earth or not - when the vast distances make it prohibitive. When debating the probability of extraterrestrials having visited earth, people always talk about the size of the universe as a reason why it is very unlikely that it ever happened.  In fact, going anywhere in interstellar space even at the speed of light would take so long it would be impractical for any organism with a life span of a century or less.  However, considering some civilizations may have been around for millions or billions of years, its definitely a possibility they have developed some means of faster than light travel, bending space, or prolonging their own lives indefinitely.  This means that the distances might not be as big a factor for a type II or type III civilization.

I think it is inevitable that alien life exists, but I don't believe that aliens will ever migrate to our planet or vice-versa. I heard about this theory a long time ago, so I may have it wrong and I don't know the name of it, but hear me out. This theory states that the universe is so huge, that nearly any probability becomes possible, however unlikely. For example, alien life is virtually certain according to the fundamental laws of probability. In addition, it is also very likely that there are aliens out there with human (or greater) intelligence. This should mean that we should have gotten a message from them by now. The likelihood is huge.

So why haven't we?

Well, the theory states that it may be that any intelligent civilization cannot progress to a point where inter-stellar travel is possible due to it depleting its planet's resources too fast. This is where it gets interesting. It could be happening to us right now. We are (arguably) on the brink of technological revolution. Within 20-30 years, things are going to be pretty crazy in the realm of science. I think this is true because of the theory that a civilization (such as the human race) progresses in the realms of sciences at the speed at which it can communicate. Therefore, scientific progress that would take 10-20-30 years in the 1800s where you had to send physical letters to people by post might only take 3-4-5 years when you can send entire bodies of work and hundreds of pages of research at the click of a button.

Now, to recap (please bear with me). We have the idea that a race cannot progress to the point where inter-stellar travel is possible, we have the knowledge that we are progressing scientifically faster than ever before, and the almost certainty that intelligent life exists out there.  

When you really think about it, it's a bit depressing. Alien life exists, but will ultimately kill itself before it can invent spaceships and we are likely to do the same. So, it seems the chances of us meeting alien life is near ZERO despite the fact tha aliens almost certainly exist out there.


(Just want to point out I may be wrong about the whole "in the next 20-30 years" prediction for amazing scientific things. In the 70s, people thought we'd be living on the moon in the year 2000. I might be over-estimating there, just to be clear. Also, this is just my view on it and is nowhere near factual. I'm only 16, so there is probably lots I still need to learn on this topic and I probably got some of the above info wrong. But, it makes sense to me, so I'd like to hear what anyone who read this far has to say about this)

There are two variables that usually don't get included in the distribution of planets argument:

The first variable that is rarely considered is the aggressive ability of life to evolve in environments that we would consider toxic, e.g. a plastics chemical waste dump which is devoid of life suddenly contains a new bacteria strain that can eat the waste. Based on this, my guess is that if the conditions for organic building blocks of life are present, then life is pretty probable. But then there's also the evolution that has to happen to evolve a sentient being capable of using radio waves for us to be able to detect it. Who knows how much life is out there at the lion/shark level of complexity?

The second variable is the geologic time scale. The probability that sentient life capable of using radio wave evolves at the same time as we did, considering the fraction of time that we have been around, is vanishingly small.

So while there most probably is life is out there, it's highly unlikely it has ever visited here. And SETI will hear their existence first. We are listening.

I think the only honest answer to this question is that we have no idea. We can't even begin to estimate the odds of life existing elsewhere than on Earth.

The reason is that although we're getting an increasingly good idea of how common Earth-like planets might be, we still don't know the first thing about how life came into existence on Earth. I don't mean evolution; I mean abiogenesis, the generation of life from non-life. Because we don't know what happened, because we have a statistical sample of a single data point (because all life on our planet at least seems to have evolved from a single shared ancestor), we simply have no way of knowing how likely life is to form.

It's possible that life coming into existence is a chemical event that takes place on most planets where the right conditions are in place. It's equally possible that life is so stupendously unlikely that 99 out of 100 universes never produce life at all. We have no idea. All we know that it is likely enough to have occured AT LEAST ONCE. :)

Exactly, and why would anyone believe such a foolish thing. 

After all, before 1992 we didn't even believe exoplanets existed. Now we've found nearly 2,000 and estimate that they're more common than stars. 

Let alone that we've known about a theoretically possible method of faster-than-light travel since 1994, Alcubierre drive.

Don't think about how over the past 150 years we've discovered and invented automobiles, powered flight, electricity, transistors, freudian psychology, genetics, agribusiness, nano technology, penicillin, radio, telephones, television, computing, the Internet, atoms, nuclear weapons, nuclear power, the four fundamental forces, special relativity, quantum physics,  space travel, indoor climate controlling, electric refrigeration, the electromagnetic spectrum, batteries, solar energy, and much, much more. 

Progress has accelerated exponentially since our invention of agriculture and the specialization of labor about 12,000 years ago. Consistent with Moore's law, there is more computing power today in a singing post card than all of Earth during WWII. Modern smart phones have 100 times the computing power of the average satellite and more power than the first space shuttle. An xbox 360 has far more computing power than the 4.5 million pound U.S. space shuttles that have 2.5 million parts.

In short, what a ludicrous idea that we'd one day discover how to implement the faster than light travel that we've already conceived of. Or that we'd invent entirely new methods. Everyone knows we're at the pinnacle of civilization today.

As I'm sure we've all figured out by now, it's a mathematical impossibility that Earth is the only planet in the galaxy, much less the universe, hosting life.

More interesting, however, is the question of have we been visited. One key point that's been on my mind for years is the existence of pyramids, so similar in shape, all over the globe, from a time when any communication between these places was not possible. Of course, the pyramid is a very basic, stable, and expandable design, so it's entirely possible that these cultures could have all come up with them on their own. Still, I find the similarities striking.

I find most of the evidence of strange lights in the sky dubious at best. First, we've been able to doctor video since it's inception, which I suspect is relatively easy for hazy balls or even sharp points of light. Second, there are still lots of energy phenomena that we don't understand in the slightest. With another few decades of research, it's entirely likely that most, if not all, of the current evidence will be explained naturally, or debunked outright, much like the crop circles that one of the people in the video failed to remember the name of.

Between the recent breakthroughs in fusion research, and the potential for imminent results in warp drive technology (I get chills just thinking about it!), there is little doubt in my mind that before the century is out, humanities reach will be expanding exponentially. Maybe then we will get some answers, and hopefully, some new questions.

How can we say anything about the odds about life in the universe if we don't know the odds of life arising from non-life?  So far we haven't been able to coax the emergence a self replicating molecule capable of reproducing and evolving from simple amino acids that we know are common in the universe.  Until that process is known, suggesting that life "probably" exists elsewhere in the universe seems premature.  For all we know, the odds of stumbling upon life could be so small that the odds of it happening twice in the universe are extremely unlikely even given the huge number of planets in the universe.  It would be like saying that if you get a million of lottery tickets you are likely to win the jackpot more than once. Not so if the odds of winning are 100 million to 1.

Due to the size of the universe, the probability of existing other life forms is higher than the probability of them encountering somehow. First, of the many life forms that could be out there, not all would be complex, multi-celled organisms. Among these, not all would be intelligent. Then, not all would be technologically advanced to the point of achieving space travel. Then, not all would have the resources or the interest to do so in a regular basis just for the sake of finding other life, due to the distances involved. So I think that it would take a lot of time for a species that meet this criteria to find another species, even a simple one. There is a possibility that humanity as a species cease to exist without ever finding other life. But I seriously hope that humanity learns to solve its problems and live enough to achieve this goal.

I think the most interesting part of this question is the combination of the Drake Equation, the Fermi Paradox, and nuclear pulse propulsion, which suggest that life is fairly likely to exist elsewhere, but it hasn't visited Earth, but that colonizing the entire galaxy should only take on the order of tens of millions of years at most. So, do most civilizations never leave their home solar system? Do civilizations destroy themselves typically? Are we likely to die out before we go elsewhere?

Alien = microbe or "Intelligent Life"? One way would be to see how easy it would be for life to start in the laboratory. A message sent at the speed of light at a near system i.e. 12 light years away would with instant response take 24 years. More than a few are 100s of light years away. Not many people have the patience, attention span, or funding to wait this long. The Apollo program is an example. For me the odds favor life more than human willingness.

The fact that most exoplanets are far away doesn't mean extraterrestrial life hasn't visited Earth. What if the society of a given species of alien has existed for just 1000 years longer than us?

This is a small amount of time in the grand scheme of things, but if you look at our own rate of technological growth over the last few centuries, you start to realize that A LOT of technology growth is possible even in just that 1000 years. Only 300 years ago, people had no idea what nuclear fission, nuclear fusion, the internal combustion engine, nuclear weapons, airplanes, helicopters, submarines, aircraft carriers, radar, computers, cell phones, the internet, skyscrapers, calculators, satellites, GPS, vaccines, nuclear medicine, ultrasounds, antibiotics, refrigeration, air conditioning, carbon nanotubes, the space shuttle, chemical weapons, biological weapons, missiles, airships, robots, the green revolution, the industrial revolution (started in 1760 according to Wikipedia), the Large Hadron Collider, the Higgs Boson, automobiles, power plants, alternating current, genetically modified crops, anesthesia,  maglevs, radio, television, pacemakers, jet engines, carbon dating, antimatter, particle accelerators, man-made elements, mammograms, sonar, [.....] - etc.

So if we did all that and more in just about 300 years, is it at all reasonable to say that in an extra 1000 years no extraterrestrial species could possibly have figured out a way to travel through the vastness of space to reach Earth? What if they had a million years of further technological growth than we did? Maybe they've ALREADY visited Earth in the past, and we just aren't aware of it.

Actually, with nuclear rockets, we could send probes to some nearby star systems already, and expect them to get there in just several decades. There are ~26 stars known to be within 12 light years of Earth. Who knows how many planets might be near Earth orbiting those stars?

It's not unreasonable to think it is probable that extraterrestrials may have traveled to Earth before. Not even close to unreasonable.

We are not dumb. You have to look at the chemical properties of a liquid and why it is extremely important for life. If a planet was just a solid, molecules would have an extremely hard time moving, molecules need to move in order for chemical reactions to occur. Without chemical reactions nothing can be created.

The biochemical reactions that sustain life need a fluid in order to operate. In a liquid, molecules can dissolve and chemical reactions occur. And because a liquid is always in flux, it effectively conveys vital substances like metabolites and nutrients from one place to another, whether it's around a cell, an organism, an ecosystem, or a planet. Getting molecules where they need to go is difficult within a solid and all too easy within a gas—vapor-based life would go all to pieces.

But does the Fermi paradox account for the fact that as a species we've only just reached the point where we can intelligently recognise what's out there and have a basic grasp of science to understand what we can see? 

The universe is 13.7 billion years old and modern science and astronomy is only a hundred years old. If we were visited in the 1200 or 1300's we probably wouldn't probably wouldn't have a clue? I'm not one for conspiracy theories but it does make you think...

At the same time, there's the Fermi paradox, which states that due to the age and size of the universe, we should have encountered alien life, but for some reason we have yet to do so.  This takes into account the size of the universe.  Even slow methods of space travel that we ourselves have almost obtained would have resulted in our contact with aliens. The age of the universe also suggests that there are species easily millions of years older than ours, so such travel should be possible.

I really don't understand why so much of the scientific community keeps calling a large number of cases by themselves a "large probability". A probability is the number of favorable cases divided by the number of possible cases. Every time you add a criteria for life requirement (like the goldilocks zone) your number of favorable cases gets smaller. If you have a large enough number of constraints (Atmosphere, iron core for radiation deflection, etc) the the probability can be really small.

What? How is that "insane"? It's statistics and probability. Example: Lets say you invite 10 people to a venue. The probability that someone will be wearing EXACTLY red Jordans, a blue baseball cap with the #10 on it, black Nike golfing gloves, yellow khaki shorts, boxers with smiley faces on them, and a gray blazer is pretty low. Now lets say you invited the entire world (7+ billion). The probability that someone is wearing EXACTLY that goes WAY up! Is it guaranteed? No, but it sure is likely.

I have no problem with saying that there might be life on other planets, in fact I think it would be cool. But expressing that there is "probably" life on other planets by merely the sheer number of statistical planets out there is insane, and shows your ignorance on the subject. Why don't you do the research on what all it takes for a planet to harbor life before making a conclusion. Statistically it's improbable. There is an other technique used to detect exoplanets, it's based on the "gravitational lens effect". A planet creates a gravitationnal field which deforms spacetime and the light following these distorsions converges mostly to a single point. So from the earth if you're able to detect a peak of brightness it is probably caused by an exoplanet.
It's not a theorem.

Hey! You forgot to mention the Fermi Paradox!
I think it's one of the most important arguments to present if you want to make a serious discussion about aliens.

Lets say that there is life on a planet in the closest of our stars (exept for the sun) alpha centuriae (it is acually three stars cirkling eachother). The system is ~4,5 lightyears away. Lets say they have technology like us, that can go 0.02% of the speed of light, then it would take them ~95,5 billion years to reach us (if i have done my maths correct). 95,5 billion years ago, the universe didnt exist. If they have übertech that can go 50% of the light, it would still take 4 billion years.

Very high in that context is somewhat connected to our understanding of the infinite.

We really have no clue whether alien life develops in every fifth star system, or only every other galaxy (so every few dozen billion star systems).

So it is a matter of perspective. For all of it... very high probability.

Most galaxies are part of galactic clusters or groups held together by gravity. Though the system is unstable, they orbit one another or the cluster's center of gravity.

Our own galaxy, Milky Way, is a member of the Local Group which has approximately 54 members. 2.5-million light-years away is the Andromeda Galaxy. It is the largest member, though a 2006 discovery suggests that it may be less massive than the Milky Way.

In the Local Group, most members orbit either the Milky Way or Andromeda.

This is the Alcubierre Drive, which requires a negative-mass shell. No negative-mass particles are known, and they are not part of the Standard Model. What NASA created was not the Drive, but an interferometer to be used in laboratory experiments that simulate some effects of the Drive using highly-charged capacitors.

It is simply off the track deduction to state that extraterrestrial life must exit because the Universe is so vast. Pure statistics: we know, kind of, the minimum possible size of the sample (the observable Universe), but we have no idea of the average probability. One occurrence, on Earth, is not enough at all to estimate.
